description: According to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, $100 million will be used to make payments to impacted borrowers in a settlement with the former servicer of student loans.
title: Navient reaches $120 million settlement for misleading student loan borrowers

description: Cocoa beans, which are used to make chocolate, are mostly grown in a few places making them susceptible to the effects of extreme weather events, driven by climate change. We hear about a team in Germany that is developing a chocolate made without cocoa.
title: Making German Chocolate Without Using Cocoa

description: The Islamic Action Front, the political wing of the Muslim Brotherhood, is now the single biggest opposition bloc in Jordan's 138-member parliament, winning one-fifth of the seats this week.
title: In Jordan's elections, anger at Israel over the Gaza war fuels Islamist gains

description: The Campbell Soup Company's CEO said the "subtle yet important change" to the name adopted in 1922 better reflects the broad number of products it makes.
title: After more than a century, the Campbell's company drops 'soup' from its name

description: At two events, Donald Trump’s New Jersey golf club hosted a convicted Jan. 6 rioter known for extreme antisemitic and racist comments, whom prosecutors described as a ‘white supremacist.’
title: Trump’s Bedminster club hosted an alleged Nazi sympathizer who stormed the Capitol

description: Water utilities across the country will have to comply with EPA limits on "forever chemicals" in drinking water by 2029. Orange County, Calif., got a head start.
title: How a California county got PFAS out of its drinking water

description: New York's highest court on Thursday dismissed an appeal from former President Donald Trump to lift the remaining gag order in his hush money case.
title: Trump must comply with gag order in New York after appeal dismissed

description: Trump has claimed that the only way he can lose on election day is if there’s voter fraud. New York Times reporter Nick Corasaniti explains the battle over the ballot box and post-election results.
title: How Democrats and Republicans are gearing up for a post-election legal fight

description: The Las Vegas Aces star surpassed the previous mark of 939 points set by Jewell Loyd in 2023. Wilson could potentially be the first WNBA player to reach 1,000 points in a year.
title: A'ja Wilson breaks the WNBA's single-season scoring record and eyes another milestone

description: The U.N. relief agency for Palestinian refugees in the Gaza Strip said its employees were among 18 people killed in an Israeli airstrike on a school. Israel said the school was being used by Hamas.
title: The U.N. says 6 staff were killed in an Israeli strike on a Gaza school

description: Nearly a dozen arts workers in New York City have recently left their jobs or been fired over conflict with their employers about expressing solidarity with Palestinian suffering.
title: NYC cultural institutions split with staff over wearing keffiyehs, Palestine solidarity

description: Bon Jovi spotted a woman on the ledge of the pedestrian bridge where his crew was filming in Nashville late Tuesday. The singer and a team member helped her over the railing and back to safety.
title: Jon Bon Jovi helps talk a woman off the ledge of a bridge while filming a music video

description: What we eat plays a role in the health of our environment. Here are some things to consider when trying to make doable changes to improve your impact without breaking the bank.
title: Sustainable eating habits that can help the environment without taking over your life

description: A new morality law is full of restrictions. No neckties for men. Photos cannot be reproduced. The harshest rules are for women — who are singing out on social media to protest the ban on singing.
title: Afghan women sing to protest a law that orders them to keep quiet

description: NPR gets a rare look inside war-torn Sudan, where millions are displaced and struggling for survival. And, we examine new data on why grocery prices remain high.
title: A rare look inside war-torn Sudan. And, the data behind grocery inflation.

description: Now that the World Health Organization has endorsed a one-dose vaccine, global health groups are amping up their effort to inoculate the world's girls. How are they doing?
title: Whatever happened to ... the global effort to wipe out cervical cancer with a vaccine?

description: An internet entrepreneur and a SpaceX engineer are on their way to becoming the first private astronauts to walk in space.
title: WATCH LIVE: SpaceX Polaris astronauts conduct the first-ever private spacewalk

description: In 2014, Susan Kahn was in the hospital with terminal cancer, unable to attend her daughter's high school graduation. So the hospital staff brought the celebration to her.
title: She couldn't go to her daughter's graduation, so the hospital brought it to her

description: You know that old line, "Tell me what you eat and I'll tell you who you are"? If that's true, then Cristeta Comerford knows the last five presidents of the United States better than almost anyone.
title: What does a busy president want to eat? This White House chef has the answer

description:
Hanif Abdurraqib's writing has earned him a MacArthur "genius" grant. His most recent book, There's Always This Year: On Basketball and Ascension, landed a spot on Barack Obama's summer reading list. But those accolades don't matter to him as much as being a good friend and neighbor. Abdurraqib talks to Rachel about a youth spent unhoused and incarcerated, and the zen of making mixtapes.

To listen sponsor-free, access bonus episodes and support the show, sign up for Wild Card+ at plus.npr.org/wildcard
title: Hanif Abdurraqib is a 'genius.' His friends aren't impressed
